0: Image copyright AP NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR Paris attacks suspect Salah Abdeslam has admitted he wanted to blow himself up but then changed his mind, a French prosecutor says. NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR Abdeslam has been charged with terrorism offences in Belgium a day after he was seized in a dramatic raid. NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR Abdeslam will fight extradition to France but has been co-operating with police, his lawyer says. NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR The Paris attacks in November left 130 people dead and dozens injured. NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR The so-called Islamic State (IS) group said it was behind the bombings and shootings. NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR Abdeslam is charged with participation in terrorist murder and the activities of a terrorist group, Belgium's federal prosecutor's office says. NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR Paris prosecutor Francois Molins told a news conference: "Salah Abdeslam today during questioning by [Belgian] investigators affirmed that, and I quote, 'he wanted to blow himself up at the Stade de France and that he had backed down'." NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR Abdeslam's assertions should be treated with caution, he added. NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR The 26-year-old French national, born in Belgium, is in custody following his arrest in Brussels on Friday after four months on the run. NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR Investigators hope Abdeslam, who was shot in the leg during his arrest, will reveal more information about the IS network behind the Paris attacks, its financing and plans. NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR They believe he helped with logistics, including renting rooms and driving suicide bombers to the Stade de France. NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR Abdeslam is believed to have fled shortly after the attacks, returning to the Molenbeek district of Brussels. NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR Molenbeek raid: As it happened NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR Salah Abdeslam's luck runs out NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR Is Molenbeek a haven for Belgian jihadis? NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR Image copyright AFP Image caption Salah Abdeslam's Belgian lawyer Sven Mary says his client will oppose extradition NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR Interpol has meanwhile urged "extra vigilance" at borders following Friday's Brussels raid, saying more accomplices may try to flee Europe. NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR Manhunt NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR The subject of a massive manhunt, Salah Abdeslam was arrested about 500m (1,600ft) from his home in Molenbeek. His brother, Brahim, was one of the Paris attackers, who blew himself up. NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR Another man arrested at the same time as Salah Abdeslam on Friday, Monir Ahmed Alaaj, has also been charged with participation in terrorist murder and the activities of a terrorist group, the Belgian prosecutors say. NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR Media caption Explosion heard during live news report on Friday NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR Friday's raid also saw three members of a family detained. NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR They include Abid Aberkan, described as a friend of Abdeslam, who has been charged with participation in the activities of a terrorist organisation and harbouring criminals. NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR Another family member, identified as Djemila M, has been charged with harbouring criminals, but is not in custody, the prosecutor's office says. NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR Abid Aberkan's mother, Sihane, has been freed and faces no charges. NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR Fingerprints NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR The raid came after Abdeslam's fingerprints were found in a flat in another Brussels district, Forest, raided on Tuesday. NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR Dramatic footage showed Abdeslam being bundled into a police car on Friday after a volley of gunfire. Alaaj was also injured during the arrests, but both suspects were discharged from hospital on Saturday. NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR French President Francois Hollande said Abdeslam's arrest was "an important moment". NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR "The battle against terrorism does not end tonight, even though this is a victory," Mr Hollande told a news conference on Friday with Belgian Prime Minister Charles Michel. NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR "We must catch all those who allowed, organised or facilitated these attacks and we realise that they are a lot more numerous than we thought earlier and had identified," he said. NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR Prosecutors said Alaaj had travelled with Abdeslam to Germany last October, where his fingerprints were taken during an identity check. NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR A false Syrian passport in Alaaj's name and Belgian identity papers under an alias were found in a flat in Forest raided on Tuesday. NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR More details have meanwhile emerged about an Algerian national, Mohamed Belkaid, shot dead in Tuesday's raid. NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR Associated Press says it has been passed documents by the Syrian opposition news site, Zaman al-Wasl, suggesting he joined IS in 2014 and asked to be a suicide bomber. NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR Belgian investigators say he is likely to have been an associate of Abdeslam. NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR Along with the Stade de France, the Paris bombings and shootings targeted the Bataclan concert hall and bars and restaurants. NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR Officials have identified most of the people they believe to have carried out the assaults and on Friday Mr Hollande predicted that more arrests could follow.
